scenes.location: NASSAU BAND REHEARSAL STUDIO GEHRING HALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cavernous space. Sound-proofed walls. And in the center DRUM SET. Seated at it, in a sweat-marked white T, eyes zeroed on his single-stroke roll, is ANDREW NEIMAN. He’s 19, slight, honors-student-skinny -- except for his arms, which have been built from years and years of drumm Suddenly -- a MAN enters the practice room. Stopping, ris

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sorry... I’m -- I’m sorry--

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It’s ok. Stay there. The MAN steps forward, removes his coat. He’s tall. Late fifties. Black T-shirt, black slacks, black shoes. We’1ll him as FLETCHER. The room is silent now. And then, softly, as he’s one of those people whose whisper can scare the crap out of you-

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Andrew Neiman, sir. (It’s pronounced “Nayman”.)

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What year are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I’m a first-year, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You know what I do?  Pink (9/10/2013) 2

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: So you know I’m looking for players.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Then why did you stop playing? Beat. Andrew nods, smiles. He gets it. Summons up all his remaining energy and resumes playing, trying to really sh off this time. Rolls, fills, speedy stick-work. He finish FLETCHER (CONT’D) Did I say to start playing again? Andrew looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I thought-- (then, blanching, ) I’m sorry, I misun--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I asked you why you stopped playing. Your version of an answer was to turn into a wind-up drummer monkey.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- I--I stopped playing becau--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Show me your rudiments. Andrew nods. Plays one rudiment after another: double-str roll, paradiddle, ratamacue, flam, flamadiddle. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Uh-huh. Double-time swing. Fletcher begins clapping his hand in time. Fast. Andrew p FLETCHER (CONT’D) No. Double-time. Double it. Bop-bop-bop- bop-bop-bop-bop-bop-bop-bop. Andrew tries doubling the tempo. But he can’t. Fletcher S CLAPPING. The sign of death. Andrew keeps playing, eyes shut... Then -- he hears the d CLOSE. He stops, and looks up. Fletcher has left the room  Pink (9/10/2013) 3 A moment later -- the door OPENS. It’s Fletcher. Andrew's eyes widen. Maybe it’s not over... FLETCHER (CONT’D) Woopsy-daisy. Forgot my coat. Fletcher grabs it, steps back out, CLOSES the door. Andre stares ahead, alone again at the drums -- and totally deflated. It’s over. WIDE SHOT of the band room as Andrew slowly rises. A titl Shaffer Conservatory of Music Fall Semester

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew exits, hurries off. Pasted onto his overloaded bac pack are patches, buttons, names: Krupa. Roach. Buddy Ric The buildings of midtown New York loom over him like gian immense, forbidding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet two-screen theater. Andrew buys concessions. The at the counter is about his age. She’s pretty, but doesn’ really know it. More to the point, she doesn’t seem to ca Her name is NICOLE.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Swedish fish?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Nah, not this time, thanks... Andrew and Nicole exchange smiles. He takes his items -- popcorn, Raisinets, two sodas -- and heads off. Peers bac Nicole. She’s staring into space. She looks suddenly lone Andrew takes in the sight. You can tell he’s attracted to -- but he’s too nervous to do anything. A beat later, he enters the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew spots a 53-year-old man seated near the front. Thi his dad -- JIM. Mild-mannered, soft-spoken, average in ev respect. Has the eyes of a former dreamer.  Pink (9/10/2013) A smile between the two of them. Andrew hands his dad the Raisinets, hands him the drink. Routine. The movie hasn’t started yet. As they exchange items--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You ok?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sure... A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He had me play today.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Andrew shrugs. It’s clear what that means.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You still have other options.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It’s good to be open-minded. When I was your age I thought I’d have a book deal at 23. Then that changed to 30. Then 40.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Right... And that didn’t upset you? Jim shrugs, keeps his eyes down. He has a tendency to loo down when talking. The lights dim. The previews begin.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, it has to do something to you.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (another shrug) I don’t know. Why? It’s just life. (pause) There's other things to care about. Friends. Romance... Andrew takes it in. Especially the last part.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At my age you get perspective.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don’t want perspective.  Pink (9/10/2013) 4a Jim smiles. A moment. Just then a MOVIEGOER squeezes into the row to head to a seat further down -- and bumps against Jim and his bucket of popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: JIM NEYMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. The Moviegoer doesn’t say a word. Andrew watches. Takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty elevator doors squeak open. Andrew steps out -- int grimy, green-walled hallway.  Pink (9/10/2013) 6 Dim lights, loud MUSIC blaring from behind a door. A thud party beat... At the end of the hall -- where the music is coming from few PARTYGOERS mingle by a door. The door opens. A YOUNG hands a SECOND YOUNG MAN a wad of cash in exchange for a lock bag of PILLS. The SECOND YOUNG MAN eyes Andrew. Andrew turns away, heads left -- to his own door. Hurried opens it and slips inside. INT. DORMITORY - ANDREW’S ROOM - NIGHT 7 A single. Drumsticks and drum pads scattered, biographies Bach and Coltrane on the shelf, posters of Louis Armstron and Charlie Parker on the walls. A TV is on, some sort of music documentary. Andrew watches from his bed -- as, ove OLD AUDIO OF DRUMMING and old stills of a boy at a drum s

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By the age of ten, Traps the Boy Wonder was wowing crowds all over America. By his teens, Buddy Rich was well on his way to becoming the stuff of legend.

dialogues.speaker: TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: Like any truly great player, Buddy seemed to have been born with music in his blood. He grasped it intuitively, ina way you and I just can't.

dialogues.speaker: TALKING HEAD
dialogues.text: You check out the old stuff, man. You look at those movies when he was a kid, his arms... Beat. Andrew takes it all in -- especially these words: TALKING HEAD #2 (0.S.) (CONT’D) You just can't teach that. That kind of genius. (pause) You either got it or you don't. Andrew turns off the TV. We hear the party beat continuin outside, muffled. He leans back and switches off his ligh WE FADE OUT.  Pink (9/10/2013) 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same room we saw Andrew practicing in at night -- onl it’s full of musicians. Mostly male, mostly first- and se years. This is NASSAU BAND, one of Shaffer’s lower-level ensembles. Because it’s Shaffer, the players are still fi rate. A few third-years are here, too -- including a red- drummer with the body of a linebacker. RYAN CONNOLLY. Andrew looks up -- in time to see Ryan with a GIRL by the doorway. Ryan’s girlfriend is gorgeous -- tall, all curve Ryan lets his hand slide down her shoulder. Andrew watche The GIRL waves bye to Ryan as he heads in. He’s all macho confidence.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPETER
dialogues.text: My man Ry! Shit, how you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Stitched up at last, dude.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPETER
dialogues.text: Things were hurting with Neiman on the kit-- Ryan taps him to stop. Andrew is within earshot -- and ha heard. Beat. Ryan moves over to Andrew, sits down at the

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You have a good weekend, bro?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah. Definitely. Really good.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about Greg. He’s a dick. Andrew nods. Admires Ryan. Seems more diminutive now than

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You been practicing?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah. All the time.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: My man. Then -- the Nassau Band conductor appears: RON KRAMER.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Morning, fellas. “Billie’s In”, bar 8.  Pink (9/10/2013) 8 Mr. Kramer CLAPS OFF in time -- and the band begins playi FIRST NASSAU BAND REHEARSAL CHART. Mid-tempo. Ryan’s confident, in control. Andrew turns his pages, watches... MR. KRAMER (CONT’D) Nice, Ryan... Woah, trumpets.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah - sorry about that one.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Just brass again. To Ryan’s left, a whisper--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPETER
dialogues.text: Ry... Ryan turns. Visible as a silhouette through the frosted g of the main door...is FLETCHER. Andrew turns and looks as well. Tenses up. kk kk kk kk Fletcher lingers outside. Then he walks on. Ryan turns ba the Trumpeter.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Not today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rehearsal has ended. The MUSICIANS have just filed out -- except for Andrew, who’s hanging back...

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Are you learning from Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah... He’s been great to me.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Last week was a little overwhelming for you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (is that a question?) Yeah... (then, hesitant, ) I wonder...what you think about my progress?

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Your progress?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I just... I’m...practicing hard and...  Pink (9/10/2013)

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Andrew -- you’ve got a good attitude. You always arrive on time. Andrew nods. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: 8A
dialogues.text: Pink (9/10/2013) MR. KRAMER (CONT’D) Yeah. Ok?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (beat) Ok... Do you think... I know Fletcher's looking for players...for Studio Band...

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Yeah, Andrew... Lincoln Center looks out for Fletcher's top players. If it weren’t for Ryan’s injury he’d have been in Studio Band last year. He’s a natural player. Andrew takes this in. Nods. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: ok.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: (this is awkward) Look... I’m going to be candid. 90% of our players will never make it into the Lincoln Centers or the Collectives. The question is -- who’s in that 10%? MR. KRAMER (CONT’D) So I'd practice. You could start a rock band. Andrew takes it in. The implication is clear. He turns -- and glimpses a poster on the wall: a DRUMMER throwing a stick in the air mid-solo. Buff. Confident. Th opposite of him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I...I have one more question... (Kramer looks at him) .-..Do you know what the process for transferring is?  10 11 12 Pink (9/10/2013) 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew walks down a hallway. A piece of paper in his hand It’s a TRANSFER APPLICATION... He notices as two attractive female students pass him. aK

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: At least you didn’t embarrass yourself aK like what’s-his-face. **

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: That was truly pathetic. aK As he continues walking, he hears music. Stops. Approache Looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the pane of glass, Andrew can see a FULL ORCHESTR Everyone looks older than in Nassau. More focused. All ey glued on Fletcher as he assumes his position... Fletcher’s right arm moves, just a hair, and the band sta fast, dazzling. Andrew watches -- in awe. The band’s play STUDIO BAND EAVESDROP CHART, and the sound is so full, so precise, so commanding. Nothing like Nassau. And suddenly -- Fletcher TURNS AROUND. His eyes meet Andr Andrew ducks out of view -- shit -- -- and hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew practices like mad, trying to nail a double-time s To his left a digital METRONOME blinks. The time set: 380 Andrew stops. Resets the metronome. 390. Resumes playing. Tries to keep up. Resets the metronome to 400. Can’t keep at all now. Struggling, sweating, hands blistering, when CRAAACK. Andrew's right drumstick SNAPS IN HALF. He stops. Spent. Looks at his hand, sweating and throbbin the blisters. Looks back at the metronome. Still beeping away. He turns Glances up ahead at a poster -- of BUDDY RICH hunched ove  Pink (9/10/2013) 10A kit, mid-solo -- tacked to the wall. Stares at the image. Then looks down -- at the PAPERWORK saw earlier. The heading: “APPLICATION TO TRANSFER”...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Pink (9/10/2013) 11 INT. ANDREW’S PRACTICE ROOM - MOMENTS LATER 12A A CD slides into a player. The title: “BUDDY RICH: BIRDLA Andrew skips ahead to the third track. Immediately, drums start. Another double-time swing. Only this one is insane fast. Even faster than Andrew was going. Andrew listens. Looks at his drum kit. Thinks. Makes a de Turns the CD off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same movie theater as before. Andrew marches in. Has goal and one goal only now. Walks up to Nicole at the counter. Takes a deep breath, a

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Hey -- look -- I -- I don’t know how to say this -- I see you in here all the time and -- I was just wondering -- (stops, collects himself, ) -- if you'd want to get a bite to eat with me. Beat. Nicole just looks at him. Andrew can’t believe he s he just said. Feels like a creep. Instantly regrets it.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Please get away from me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, I -- I didn’t mea--

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’m kidding. She smiles. Beat. Andrew manages a nervous laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That your dad you always come in with?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (discombobulated, trying to keep up--) Kind of bobs up and down when he walks? That’s him.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (laughs; then, ) Andrew, right? I’m Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Nicole...  14 15 Pink (9/10/2013) 12

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Monday I get off at seven.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Monday. Ok. Great. I’1ll be here Monday. A moment -- an awkward silence -- then Andrew turns -- an in a daze, realizing what’s just happened, his spirits suddenly starting to soar -- he glides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. Andrew, still riding high, is seated in lobby outside the DEAN’s OFFICE. In his hand -- a FILLED- TRANSFER APPLICATION.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Andrew Neiman? (Andrew turns) Dr. Fletcher would like to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh. Ok... Andrew's thoughts are elsewhere. Distracted -- not sure w this is about but doesn’t really care -- he dutifully fol INT. GEHRING HALL - FLETCHER’S OFFICE - DAY 15 BLACK. We hear knocking.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come in. A door opens -- the black gives way -- and we see, seated a polished mahogany desk, Fletcher. He looks as imposing and as well-dressed -- as ever. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Hey, Andrew! I guess Sophie found you? Andrew is taken aback. Fletcher remembers his first name?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes... I’m... I--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Come in, come in, close the door... Fletcher rises to greet Andrew, as Andrew closes the door  Pink (9/10/2013) 13 FLETCHER (CONT’D) I like to chat with students coming in and going out. I hear you’re going out? Andrew looks surprised by the warmth in Fletcher’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. Transferring. To Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Terrific. Columbia’s a terrific school. Did something precipitate this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I just decided to... (not sure how to say it) +..to try out some other things. Not focus only on drums. You know? Beat. Fletcher looks at him. Is he upset? Dismayed?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Bravo. (as he starts to head back toward his desk--) Too many students clamp down on their “pursuits” like leeches. (sits atop his desk) Hobbies they picked up in their teens, and for what? Take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (starts heading to a couch) Uh... Yeah.. I mean, I -- (passes by a “lst Place Prize” plaque on a coffee-table) -- I was a little younger than my teens when I started drums, but--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What were you then? Twelve?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, kids start swimming when they’re six, doesn’t mean they’re Michael Phelps. It’s a hobby, never anything you consider going all the way with. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Definitely. I mean -- well -- for a time, I thought I’d go all the way -- but, yeah--  Pink (9/10/2013) 14

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Well, kids want anything. I wanted to be a nanny. Thank God those I trusted talked me out of it. Good to listen to advice.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve done that, you’re right, it’s--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: --good to get outside perspectives. So long as they don’t have ulterior motives, I’'d listen to what the people you trust tell you. Andrew nods. But that phrase seems to echo. Ulterior moti Fletcher hops down from the desk and makes his way to the couch. FLETCHER (CONT’D) So what's the passion you've chosen to pursue at Columbia, then?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (as Fletcher takes a seat next to him) Oh... Well... I’m not...not really sure. It’s not a specific thing I have in mind.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Ah. Well that’s ok. You’re young. Most people, it takes years for them to find their calling. My father, for instance -- he had no idea what he wanted at your age. He tried a lot of things, a little bit of this, a little bit of that. Took him years before he realized his dream was insurance. That was his passion. The cubicle, the coffee breaks, the dry wall. He lets this simmer for a beat. Then-- FLETCHER (CONT’D) I’m sure you'll find your calling as well. He rises back up. A moment of silence. FLETCHER (CONT’D) I guess that’s it, then. Any questions? He notices Andrew looking at a photo on the wall.  He takes standing drift to walls... JVC Jazz Pink (9/10/2013) 15 FLETCHER (CONT’D) That’s Sean Casey. Graduated three years ago. Now he’s first trumpet at Lincoln Center. (heading toward the door--) He came a long way.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (trying to collect his thoughts as he rises) +..SO -- are you -- still looking for Studio Band players then...?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (turning around to face Andrew) Some, yes. But it’s no cakewalk. Most kids here can’t last. Laszlo Polgar, Hungarian psychologist, declares in 1967 that talent is all about conditioning. Says he can make his kids, whoever they are, the best in the world at something. What that something is he'll decide. He’s a lousy chess player but he picks chess because it’s objective. Goes around looking for a wife, finds one who agrees to his experiment. Starts having kids: Susan, Sofia and Judit. Gets them practicing before they can even talk. These weren’t kids who were sitting and smelling the roses. These were kids who were going to leave an actual mark on the world. Who was the top female player by 1984? Susan. Who played the eight-straight-wins “Miracle of Rome” in 1989? Sofia. And who is universally considered the greatest female chess player of all time? Judit. a breath. Smiles. We linger for a second on Andrew, in place, taking it all in. Andrew’s eyes quickly the photos behind Fletcher -- the images on the The Studio Band with Wynton Marsalis. Fletcher at the Festival. One jazz luminary after another... FLETCHER (CONT’D) Which is why I’m sure you’1l be great at whatever you set your mind to at Columbia. (puts his arm around Andrew, starts escorting him toward the door--) It was a pleasure chatting, Andrew, now--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I just -- one thing first -- I mean -- I’m not entirely sure I’m transferring yet...  16 Pink (9/10/2013) 16

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Well that’s worrisome. I’m sure you had good reason to make your decision.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I -- just might give it some more time--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: No need to do that. First instincts are best.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: My first instinct...is not to transfer...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure your first instinct is right, then. Why don’t you give it some more thought, and in the meantime... (reaches the door; about to close--) ---make sure your double-time swing is ready by Monday’s Nassau Band. He closes the door. WE LINGER on Andrew. A spark has been

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew plays the drums with Nassau Band. Keeps missing hi The song’s SECOND NASSAU BAND REHEARSAL CHART (ANDREW).

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Alright, that’s... That’s enough of that. Back to just the core, please. MUSICIANS trade places. As Ryan trades with Andrew, he tu

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Dude -- what’ve you been practicing? Just then, the DOOR SWINGS OPEN -- and in steps FLETCHER. eyes go to him. All talking ceases. Absolute silence, sav Fletcher’s footsteps. Andrew waits. Heart pounding... Fletcher arrives at the head of the band -- as Kramer sil and meekly retreats. Fletcher props up the music stand to height, looks down at the sheet music, runs his finger do to find the spot he wants... Andrew, like all the other players, is dead-still, eyes glued on Fletcher’s every mo Fletcher looks up, surveys the band with his eyes. Then, his hand--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Down the line.  Pink (9/10/2013) 17 Instruments SNAP upward with military precision. No one w to miss a beat. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Trumpets. Bars 36 to 38. One-two-- The TRUMPETER on the right starts playing. Five notes bef Fletcher cuts him off with the slightest flick of his han

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next. One-two-- (the SECOND TRUMPETER misses his cue) Next. One-two-- Nothing. Fletcher looks up. There are no more trumpeters. looks over at Kramer: “Are you serious?" FLETCHER (CONT’D) Trombone. Bars 21 to 23. Four-and-- (TROMBONIST is scrambling to find the right page) Saxes. 48 to 50. “And” of one. And-one-- (ALTO SAX gets through one bar) Next-- Before he even counts off, he notices the TENOR SAX’s fingering -- all he needs to know.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drums. We get a split-second glimpse of the TENOR SAXOPHONIST, wondering what just happened -- before we CUT to the drum Ryan at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Double-time swing. Ryan takes a breath. Fletcher CLAPS him off. Ryan plays. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Thank you. You. Behind. Palms sweaty, Andrew takes Ryan’s place. Trains his eyes Fletcher’s hands. Deep breath. Fletcher CLAPS, and Andrew -- trying to get the motion right, trying to stay in time FLETCHER (CONT’D) Thank you. Bass. Five bars of “Donna Lee”. We STAY ON Andrew as the BASSIST plays; Andrew slides off drums and back to his regular seat.  17 Pink (9/10/2013) 18 FLETCHER (0.S.) (CONT’D) (to Bassist) Thank you. We CUT back to Fletcher. He looks over the band once more see the MUSICIANS’ faces -- scared, but hopeful. Then-- FLETCHER (CONT’D) Drums. Come with me. Ryan’s heart starts speeding. His excitement visible, he- FLETCHER (CONT’D) Other drums. Ryan freezes. Andrew is stuck in place for a moment. Then eyes wide -- is this really happening? -- he rises and approaches the doorway... There, Fletcher hands him an OR PAPER SLIP. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Give this to Admin for rescheduling. We meet 6am to lpm every day. Room B16. And with that, he EXITS. In a daze, Andrew drifts back toward the band. Kramer loo him. Andrew answers the look with a defiant smile. Vindic

dialogues.speaker: MR. KRAMER
dialogues.text: Ok fellas, let’s...let’s take it back from the top.. He claps off. The band plays SECOND NASSAU BAND REHEARSAL (RYAN). Andrew pretends not to notice Ryan’s eyeing him i shock. Just sits down, lets it all settle. And -- ever so slowly -- Andrew's face dissolves into a G

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: This is a nice place. We're at a cheap pizzeria now. Nicole is seated, two half eaten slices of pepperoni in front of her. An old jazz tr is playing -- PIZZERIA CHART. Seated across from Nicole is Andrew -- echoes of the earl grin still on his face, a brightness in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah, I come here a lot.  Pink (9/10/2013) 19 Beat. Then -- clicking back to reality -- this is not a n place, did I fuck up? --

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They have good music, so I -- it’s not just the food... (points, re: the tune) This is Jackie Hill, “When I Wake”, July 17th, 1938, Bob Ellis on drums.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Are you trying to impress me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No -- sorry -- I didn’t mean -- they have like -- ten songs they loop through. They’re always playing the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And you know the dates to all ten?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: ...Yeah. Nicole smiles. A moment. Andrew fidgets. Nervous.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You know every time I saw you in the theater you always had your eyes pointed to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Like you were fascinated by the soda stains on the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: My dad tells me I have a problem making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: My parents like to criticize me too. When I was growing up my mom told me my chin was too big and that that’s why guys wouldn’t like me. ‘Cause my dad had cursed me with a big chin.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s -- look -- (she turns, points her chin up) It’s Jay Leno. Andrew laughs. Nicole looks prettier to him than ever.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She keeps asking me if I have a boyfriend yet, and then blames it on the chin.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She sounds insane.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: She wanted to be an actress when she was my age.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: And you? What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Other than serving you popcorn?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What do you want to do with your life?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: (thinks; wasn’t prepared for a question that direct) I go to Fordham... I’m not sure...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What’s your major?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I don’t have one yet.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Well what did you come here to study?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I just came here for a general education.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Right, but you picked Fordham for a reason. Why Fordham?  Pink (9/10/2013) 21

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I applied to a bunch of schools, Fordham let me in. Why’d you pick Shaffer?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's the best music school in the country. Beat. Nicole shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Well Fordham was Fordham. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t love it there to be honest...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I mean -- the people there... I don’t think they like me. I’m from Arizona and -- I don’t know, I think they see it in me. A beat. Andrew thinks about this, then--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don’t like the people at Shaffer either. But I think it just takes time... Things change, you know.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I know. (then, opening up more than she expected, more fragility in her voice now) I feel homesick sometimes. You know? I hate how people in college pretend they never feel homesick. Or maybe I’m literally the only one, but... I don’t think so. A moment of silence. She looks at Andrew. He looks at her

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I know exactly how you feel. (then, he smiles) I still go to the movies with my dad. Nicole nods. Smiles back. Andrew said it playfully, but s can tell he also meant it to reach out to her.  18

dialogues.speaker: 20A
dialogues.text: Pink (9/10/2013) 22 She scoots her legs. Her knee happens to touch Andrew's. notices. So does she. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: .-.I like this song.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah -- this part is great -- here -- Nicole smiles. Looks at Andrew. He looks back. Their knee stay still, just barely touching. And, on this moment, just as the song ends -- INT. DORMITORY - ANDREW’S ROOM - PRE-DAWN 18 Andrew's in bed -- fast asleep. Seems stress-free for onc his body totally relaxed, his mind deep in a dream. His a hits his night stand -- WAKING him up. His eyes open. He at his alarm clock. It reads: 5:17.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Shi--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew bursts out of his room and RACES down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew DASHES across the green. It’s still pitch black ou the city cold and menacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew busts inside, runs down the STAIRWELL -- and SLIPS Falls full-throttle down a whole flight, hands smacking against the tile. Rises, sore, and keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew reaches ROOM B16 -- pushes open the doors--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --only to find the room EMPTY. No one is there. Andrew ch the time on his phone: 5:33. Did he miss them...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew steps back into the hallway. Spots a SIGN-UP SHEET the door. Looks at it. Sees the words “STUDIO BAND” scrol down for each day. The listed start-time: “9AM”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew sits on the drum throne. A clock on the wall reads 8:57. He’s dozed off, is out cold. His hand, cut from his down the stairs, rests against the snare drum. Suddenly -- the DOOR opens --

dialogues.speaker: SAXOPHONIST
dialogues.text: She told me to pull out, then wet the whole fucking bed.

dialogues.speaker: SAXOPHONIST
dialogues.text: No, serious?? Andrew shoots up. Surges to his feet. The SAXOPHONISTS do him any attention. They’re big guys, macho. Another DOOR MORE PLAYERS... These are the CORE MEMBERS of Studio Band -- Shaffer’s cr of the crop. Mostly third- and fourth-years. All male. A ALTERNATES follow, first- and second-years. Andrew watches as the PLAYERS buzz their mouthpieces, whi open their folders, pull out their instruments. A flurry chatter and activity... One of the CORE MEMBERS heads to the drums: CARL TANNER, Andrew sees him, and--

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: You the new alternate?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I’m -- Andrew Neiman...

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (couldn't care less about his name) Tune the set to a B-flat. Then you’ll turn my pages during rehearsal.  Pink (9/10/2013) 24 Andrew, nervous, sits back down at the drums and--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (to the PIANIST) Excuse me? (no answer) Um -- sorry -- excuse me? (the Pianist looks at him) Could I have a B-flat please? The Pianist plays a B-flat. Andrew tunes. By now the room filled: TRUMPETS, TROMBONES, SAXES.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the Pianist) Excuse me -- could I maybe have ano-- But Carl has already risen. Ushers Andrew back up. Sits d the drums, as Andrew sits down by the music stand.

dialogues.speaker: SAXOPHONIST
dialogues.text: Milk the cunt!! The PIANIST plays a middle C, and the players start tunin it. Andrew watches, listens -- the sea of sounds building, th on the wall ticking, until -- it hits 9:00. THE DOOR BURSTS OPEN. Fletcher marches in, carrying a sta of sheet music. Sudden tension -- and utter silence. Fletcher sets his music down. Stares at the band. Dead-se silently judging. A moment passes... Then -- he SMILES. He’s switched all of a sudden to warm cuddly.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: We’ve got a squeaker today, people. Neiman. (he pronounces it “Neeman”) Nineteen years old. Isn't he cute? Laughs throughout the room. We can overhear a few snicker

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Neee-man... Andrew looks. Fletcher keeps his smile up... And then--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Alright, gang. “Whiplash”.  Pink (9/10/2013) 25 The players get out the chart. Andrew catches a glimpse - a messy clutter of notes and time signatures... Fletcher raises his hand. Total silence. Then -- the slightest move of Fletcher's finger, and the band begins WHIPLASH STUDIO BAND REHEARSAL CARL #1. The chart’s named “Whiplash” for a reason. It’s fast, frenetic, 7/4 time. T fast, with this many polyrhythms, it’s impossibly hard.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Page... Page... Andrew turns the page. Carl glares. Shouldn’t have had to him to turn it. But Andrew can’t follow. The band’s too f

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Stop. You. Barker. (pointing to the THIRD TRUMPETER’S horn) That is not your boyfriend’s dick. Do not come early. Moving ahead. Bar 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players flip their sheet music. Andrew catches a glim of a TROMBONIST ejecting the spit from his horn. A puddle formed by his feet. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Five-six-seven-- The band plays WHIPLASH STUDIO BAND REHEARSAL CARL #2. Intense, visceral. Fletcher paces back and forth, eyeing players as they play. He’s got fox’s ears, hawk’s eyes. E sinew of his body is focused. Andrew watches, awed, scare completely overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop! The band comes to a halt. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Now this one upsets me. We have an out-of- tune player. Before I go any further, does that player want to do the right thing and reveal himself? (silence) Ok. Maybe a bug flew in my ear. Bar 115. Five-six-and-- He cues the BAND with his hand, then cuts them off.  Pink (9/10/2013) 26 FLETCHER (CONT’D) No, I guess my ears are clean because we most definitely have an out-of-tune player. Whoever it is, this is your last chance. (paces back and forth, slowly) Either you know you are out of tune, and are therefore deliberately sabotaging my band; or you do not know you’re out of tune -- which I’m afraid is even worse. Nothing. The players avert his gaze. All terrified... FLETCHER (CONT’D) Reeds. Five-six-and-- (they play, he cuts them off) Bones. Five-six-and-- (they play, he cuts them off) Ahhhh, he’s here. Silence. He eyes the TROMBONISTS. Lands on one, METZ. Ove Been picked on his whole life. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Tell me it’s not you, Elmer Fudd. Metz sits there, trembling. On the brink of tears. FLETCHER (CONT’D) It’s ok. Play. (Metz does so, Fletcher stops him, leans in, whispers--) Do you think you’re out of tune? Metz, terrified, looks down at the floor. FLETCHER (CONT’D) There’s no fucking Mars Bar down there. Look at me. Do you think you're out of tune?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Then why the FUCK didn’t you say so?!? Silence. It’s the first time we’ve heard Fletcher really His voice is booming, louder than one would have thought. FLETCHER (CONT’D) I’ve been carrying your fat ass for too long, Metz. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 Pink (9/10/2013) 27 FLETCHER (CONT’D) I will not let you cost us a competition because your mind’s on a fucking Happy Meal and not on pitch. Stein, congratulations, you are now fourth-chair trombone. Metz -- get the fuck out. Still trembling, tears bubbling out, Metz picks up his trombone and walks to the door. Andrew watches -- shocked Once the door closes-- FLETCHER (CONT’D) For the record, Metz was not out of tune. You were, Wallach. But Metz didn’t know it. And that’s bad enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then -- he looks straight at Andrew. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Alright, take ten. When we get back -- the squeaker’s on. Andrew's face goes ghost-white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew sits in the corner of the hall, the “WHIPLASH” she music in his hand. Tries desperately to count the beats..

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Five-six-seven... Six-two-two-five... He scribbles on the page, trying to compute the patterns: + 7/4 = 7/18". “1/64 X 7/9"... We see feet pass by, and h

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO CORE MEMBER
dialogues.text: Stein won’t last a week. He doesn’t have the lips.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO CORE MEMBER
dialogues.text: Fudd lasted longer than he should have...

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO CORE MEMBER
dialogues.text: Maybe if he spent half the time practicing that he does to polishing off cheeseburgers...

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO CORE MEMBER
dialogues.text: (laughs) You got that right. Andrew's eyes follow the PLAYERS. They’re tall, built. Ne to them Andrew feels like a scrawny teen. kk kk kk kk kk kk kk  Pink (9/10/2013) 27A Just then -- a PAIR OF DRESS SHOES reach Andrew's side. Startled, Andrew looks up. It’s Fletcher. Andrew scramble his feet, as Fletcher puts his arm over him and -- earnes back to the warm tone he displayed days ago --

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (walking Andrew down the hall) Listen, Andrew. I know what you saw in there is worrying you, but there’s a big difference. This is your first day. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Metz had been dragging mud for two years. (comes to a stop, looks straight at Andrew--) Besides, you’re no Elmer Fudd. This is a huge opportunity for you. You know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Your parents musicians?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, not really...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What do they do?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Well, my dad’s a writer.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What's he written?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Well he’s...I guess he’s mainly a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: College?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Pennington High.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: And your mom?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don’t know... She left when I was a baby.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: So no musicians in the family.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: ...-No, I guess not...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Well, you’ve just got to listen to the greats then. Jo Jones, Buddy Rich. You know, Charlie Parker became “Bird” because Jones threw a cymbal at his head. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see what I’m saying? (Andrew nods) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The key is -- relax. Don’t worry about the numbers or what the other players think. You’re here for a reason. You believe that, don’t you? (Andrew nods) Say it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I’m here for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Good. A beat. And, finally-- FLETCHER (CONT’D) Now have fun. He pats Andrew on the back -- then promptly walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are taking their seats. Slowly, Andrew walks Eyes the DRUMS. Takes a deep breath. He can do this... Carl is seated in the alternate’s seat. The drum throne i empty. Just waiting for Andrew... Andrew sits down. WE MOVE IN CLOSER ON HIM -- as he adjus his seat, lays his music out, gets his sticks ready...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Alright, gang. Andrew looks up. Fletcher has just entered.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Whiplash”. Fletcher eyes Andrew. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Neiman -- just do your best. Andrew nods. Looks at the music. Counts in his head. He's ready... Fletcher CLAPS the band off. WHIPLASH STUDIO BAND REHEARS ANDREW #1, mid-tempo, far easier than before. Andrew’s do well. Fletcher nods, smiles-- FLETCHER (CONT’D) Let’s see some fills.  Pink (9/10/2013) 30 Andrew fills, rolling down the toms. Fletcher grins. Andrew, seeing Fletcher's grin, can’t help but smile. Get into it now. The whole BAND building, his drumming growin intense. He fills again. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Snap! We've got Buddy Rich here. Andrew grins. Fills again. Accenting, playing a counter-r When he trips up. Comes in a hair late. FLETCHER (CONT’D) (waving the band to stop) Ok, little trouble there. No problem. Let’s pick it up from 17. Fletcher claps. Andrew plays WHIPLASH STUDIO BAND REHEARSAL ANDREW #2. Fletcher waves him to stop again. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Not my tempo. Ok? Fletcher claps again. Then another wave for Andrew to sto FLETCHER (CONT’D) Downbeat on 18. Ok? He’s still soft, calm, warm. He claps again. Then, stoppi FLETCHER (CONT’D) The “and” of 4. Bar 17, the “and” of 4. He claps off. Stops Andrew again, only seconds later. FLETCHER (CONT’D) 17, the “and” of 4. Ok? And you're rushing a little... Andrew nods. Getting nervous now... Fletcher claps again. again. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Not quite my tempo. All good, here we go. He’s about to clap off when, out of nerves, Andrew hits h bass drum early. FLETCHER (CONT’D) No -- ready? Fletcher claps. Stops Andrew yet again.  Pink (9/10/2013) 31 FLETCHER (CONT’D) Sorry, you’re -- you’re dragging a little now. (Andrew tries to pull his seat up, getting anxious, flustered) All set? Andrew nods. Get it together... Fletcher claps. Stops. FLETCHER (CONT’D) You’re rushing. Claps again. Stops again.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dragging. Claps again. Andrew plays WHIPLASH STUDIO BAND REHEARSAL ANDREW #3, expecting another stop -- but it doesn’t come. Fletcher nods, as though now satisfied, then slowly turns around. Puts his hand on a spare chair. Looks like he’s about to sit down, when... like a flash of lightning he WHIPS up the chair and HURLS it straight at Andrew’s head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew DUCKS, as the chair CATCHES the top of the bass dr almost toppling it over. An EAR-PIERCING CLANG OF CYMBALS Andrew's sticks go flying and the chair hits the floor. Then -- total silence in the room. Andrew is shell-shocke beyond shaken, what in the fuck just happened???... FLETCHER (CONT’D) (as though discussing the weather) Why do you suppose I just hurled a chair at your head, Neiman?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I... I... I d--don’t kn--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Yes, you do.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I... The...the tempo...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Were you rushing or were you dragging?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I... I don’t... I don’t--  Pink (9/10/2013) 32 Fletcher BOUNDS up to him, almost RUNNING -- suddenly bea like, terrifying, veins set to BURST--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Start counting.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (like a deer in the headlights) ...Five-six-seven--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: In four, damnit!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: One-two-three-four... Fletcher SLAPS Andrew on his left cheek. Then--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Keep counting!!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: One-two-- (another slap) --three-- (a third slap) --four--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Was I rushing or I was dragging?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I -- I don’t -- I don’t know--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Start counting again.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: One-two-- (a slap on his left cheek) --three-four-o-- (another slap) --ne-two-three--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Was I rushing or was I dragging?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: R--rushing...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: So you do know the difference! If you dare to sabotage my band I will fuck you like a pig. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now are you a rusher, are you a dragger, or are you going to be ON MY FUCKING

dialogues.speaker: TIME
dialogues.text: This is a new Fletcher we’re seeing. An animal. But no on but Andrew seems surprised--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I--I’m gonna be on your time...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (flips over a new sheet of music, points to the top) What does this say?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: 260... Quarter note 260...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Count a 260.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: O-one-two-three-four...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Jesus fucking Christ -- I didn’t know they allowed retards into Shaffer! Do you expect me to believe you can’t read tempo? Can you even read music??? (points back to the music) What the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: A half-note...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: And this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: A--a dotted sixteenth...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Sight-read this measure.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Bop-bop-ba-bop-ba--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: What are you, in a fucking a capella group?? Play the goddamn set!! Andrew plays the measure on the drums. Shaking, terrified  Pink (9/10/2013) 34 FLETCHER (CONT’D) Now answer my question -- were you rushing or were you dragging? (because Andrew hesitates--)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: R--r--r--rushing...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Dear God, is that a tear in your eye? Are you one of those single-tear people? Do I look like a double fucking rainbow to you?? Andrew tries to hide his tear, mortified, wipes it, cower FLETCHER (CONT’D) You must be upset. Are you upset??

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Oh so you don’t give a shit about any of this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, I -- I do give a sh--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: So are you upset? Yes or fucking no.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You are upset...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I am upset...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Say it so the rest of the band can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I am upset...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Louder.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I am upset!  24 Pink (9/10/2013) 35

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I am upset!!!

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You are a worthless friendless faggot-— lipped little piece of shit, whose Mommy ran out on Daddy once she realized he wasn’t Eugene O’Neill, and who’s now weeping and slobbering over my drum kit like a fifteen-year-old girl -- so for the last father-fucking time, SAY IT LOUDER!!!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (tears pouring out now)

dialogues.speaker: I_AM UPSET
dialogues.text: Then -- silence. Andrew hunches over the drum set, shakin face awash in tears. The other PLAYERS just stare...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Carl... Carl silently switches places with Andrew at the set. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Start practicing harder, Neiman. (then, turning to the band,) “Whiplash”. Once more from the top. He claps the band off. As for Andrew, he just sits behind dazed, red-faced, and utterly gutted. His first day of Studio Band is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew exits. Trying to hold it all in. Then--

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Hey, bro. He sees Ryan, a few yards away. Andrew hides his face, hi the TEARS that are starting to spill out uncontrollably..

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never said congrats, man. Congra-- +..and RUNS like hell.  25 Pink (9/10/2013) 36 INT. DORMITORY - ANDREW’S ROOM - DUSK 25 Andrew is curled in the corner, crying. We linger here. Then, his PHONE rings. He looks at it. Hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: ..-Hello...?

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You didn't show. And, finally, breaking down, can’t hold it in any longer-

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: He ripped me apart...

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...Who? (then, ) That asshole? You told me you were transferring... Andrew looks at his desk. There, atop a pile of papers, i his TRANSFER APPLICATION. All filled out. Ready to go. Ne to it, a BUDDY RICH CD...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) --.I thought he liked my playing.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who cares what he likes? Who is he to you? When I started writing plenty of people tried to put me down. You ignore them. Andrew is silent. When I started writing... Those words seem to have the opposite effect Jim intended

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: When you started writing...

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why don't you come home tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, I -- I have to practice.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, you have to take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I need to go now...  26 27 28 Pink (9/10/2013) 37

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Andrew--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I have to go... Sorry. I’1l call you later. He hangs up. Rises. Wipes his reddened eyes. And exits hi

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Yes? INT. GEHRING HALL - STUDIO BAND ROOM - FLETCHER’S OFFICE Andrew steps into Fletcher’s office. Before Fletcher can word--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to interrupt you. I just want to tell you -- I’m so thankful to have been accepted into Studio Band. And I’m going to make sure I don’t disappoint you. Fletcher, seated at his desk, just looks at Andrew. Andre nods, turns around. Marches back down the hall -- as PERC begins... WE FOLLOW HIM, sticking close to his face, the resolve now in his eyes. Something has changed. PERCUSSION grows louder and, as we move, hurdles us back. ...to FLETCHER’S OFFICE. And to Fletcher, peeking out through his doorway now. Fletcher smiles... INT. ANDREW’S PRACTICE ROOM - DAY 27 Andrew sits at his drum set, furiously practicing... And just like that, moving fast, DRUM PATTERN FOR MONTAGE carrying us, we’re--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Andrew's hand, Xerox-ing pages of music. The tit “WHIPLASH”, “ALEPH NULL”, “EASY SIX”... Pages dense with  29 30 31 32 33 34 35 36 Pink (9/10/2013) 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fletcher steps outside. It’s drizzling a bit. He slowly u an umbrella. Passes by a few other FACULTY MEMBERS on his to the sidewalk. Keeps walking. The DRUMMING continues... INT. DORMITORY - ANDREW’S ROOM - EVENING 30 Andrew pulls the MATTRESS off his bed, drags it to the do with his ALARM CLOCK. Heaves both out to the hallway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fletcher is seated, squished in between commuters, towere over by other travelers. Looks diminutive in this setting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew marches down a side-street, wolfing down a McDonal burger for dinner, earphones plugged into a METRONOME...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew lifts a 50-lb weight with his right arm. Then a 75 Then picks his stick up and plays his double-time swing.. EXT. FLETCHER’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT 34 Fletcher reaches a nondescript high-rise. With his folded umbrella, his head hanging low, and the careful delicacy which he opens the door, he looks here like nothing so mu as a quiet, everyday man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew sleeps, earphones still in and metronome still on. He’s on the MATTRESS he brought down from his dorm, the A CLOCK by his side. Next to it, a suitcase of clothes. Abo the poster of Buddy Rich. It’s as though he’s moved in. INT. FLETCHER’S APARTMENT - DINING ROOM - NIGHT 36 Fletcher sets the table for dinner. He has nice porcelain plates, and a glass of red wine. But the meal? A frozen r made steak and vegetables. On the wall, a photo. In it, a younger Fletcher, and a WOMAN, and a NINE-YEAR-OLD GIRL. smiles...  37 38 39 Pink (9/10/2013) 39 INT. ANDREW’S PRACTICE ROOM - MORNING 37 Andrew rises from the same mattress and slides onto his d seat. Starts playing, hands dotted with blisters, eyes cr with sand. The METRONOME still on... ...because it was never turned off. CUT TO: Rides furiously, trying to beat his double-time swing... The METRONOME reading 380... His muscles exhaust CUT TO: The METRONOME adjusted up to 390... Blisters tear cuT TO: 400.. Hands bleeding now, blood smearing the stic CUT TO: 405... The METRONOME going crazy now... The DRUMM fast it’s a wash, a wall of sound, blood on the cymbal-- INT. FLETCHER’S APARTMENT - DINING ROOM - NIGHT 38 Silence. Fletcher finishes his meal. Puts the dishes away down on a couch. Still alone. The apartment, like his office, is small but elegant. Pic of icons on the walls. Monk. Holiday. Coltrane... Fletcher reaches into a stack of LP’s: Chopin, Ravel... P one out with the most delicate touch, as though he were handling a newborn. Sets it on a record player by his sid A scratch, a hiss, and then -- -- FLETCHER’S SONG. Melancholy, lovelorn... Fletcher just sits and listens, barely moves -- but you c tell the music now playing means everything to him... A moment, and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild, feverish, absurdly fast BIG BAND JAZZ. We're on-sta An orchestra about the size of Studio Band is in full swi reaching the end of RIVAL OVERBROOK BAND CHART.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band FINISHES. No applause. A card: First Competition of the Winter Season

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RIVAL PLAYERS quickly shuffle into the green room, pa Andrew, who watches, awed. A VOICE--

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Terry! Andrew turns, glimpses a CORRIDOR through the doorway. Ou the corridor, he sees a TECHNICIAN welcome Fletcher. In t Technician’s arms, a FOUR-YEAR-OLD GIRL -- the Technician daughter --

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Mike! (and, to the girl,) I’m so sorry, can I have your autograph? (she blushes, shakes her head) Are you playing an instrument yet?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: She started piano this week.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Ooo, I need pianists! (to the girl) What do you say, you ready for Carnegie Hall? The Technician smiles again, looks at the girl. She hides face in his chest, embarrassed. He and Fletcher laugh. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Alright, alright. (looking up at her dad) Great to see you, Mike. He leans in. They hug. FLETCHER (CONT’D) See you after the show! Cheers! He steps in, closes the door and addresses his PLAYERS, w are busy sanding their hands, buzzing their lips, prepari FLETCHER (CONT’D) Ok, you fucking cocksuckers. E Dorian. (the non-percussion players lift their instruments) Hurry the fuck up!! E Dorian. (they play the Dorian scale) Double it. (they play it double-time) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l Pink (9/10/2013) 41 FLETCHER (CONT’D) G Lydian. (they play the Lydian scale) D Lydian Augmented. (they play it) Double it. (they play it double-time) Get your music. “Irene” only for Set 1. Rhythm section out first. Tanner, the kit is a tonal catastrophe. Get it in tune. Rhythm and soloists, we're augmenting the dominant in measure 45. Everyone else sharp the nine at bar 106. Got it? (beat) Now remember. Lincoln Center and its ilk use these competitions to decide who they want. And I am not about to have my record in that department stained by a bunch of sour-note flexible-tempo flatter- than-their-girlfriends dipshits. And another thing... (he holds up a music folder) ...if I ever see one of these lying about unattended to again, I swear to God I will stop being so polite. That alright with you, ladies?

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS
dialogues.text: Yes. A STAGEHAND approaches Fletcher, about to speak to him--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: (almost matter-of-fact) Get the fuck out of my sight before I demolish you. The STAGE HAND nods, slinks away. Fletcher addresses his FLETCHER (CONT’D) Stage right. In order. Now. (turns to the STAGE HAND -- who's short and plump) That means you too, Mini-Me. INT. DUNELLEN AUDITORIUM - STAGE - CONTINUOUS 4l Studio Band goes on-stage. Carl hurries to the DRUMS, tun

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Stick bag. Andrew hands Carl the stick bag. Raises the music stand, the MUSIC FOLDER onto it--  42 43 Pink (9/10/2013) 42

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCEMENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Shaffer Conservatory Studio Band...

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Hurry up. --and opens it to OVERBROOK COMPETITION CHART. Fletcher appears. Raises his hand. Everyone raises their instruments. Sits still. Waiting... A cough is heard. Fletcher looks to his right. The player stay still. No sign of whom it came from... And then -- the slightest move of Fletcher’s index finger subtle you need absolute focus to even notice it. That’s count-off. Miss it and you’ve blown it for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAND LAUNCHES. Quiet at first, then a big brassy soun Andrew watches Carl’s playing. Taps along on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Page. (Andrew snaps to it, turns the page) Damnit... Still conducting, Fletcher approaches, whispers--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Get it together, Tanner, I swear to God. Heads back to his position, glaring at Carl. Pissed at An Carl plays. The music BUILDS and we’re--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The performance over, the PLAYERS trickle BACKSTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (handing Andrew the folder, still pissed) Hold onto this for the second set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew plugs in for a can of Coke at a vending machine. S his MUSIC FOLDER down on a chair. Keeps his eyes on it.  Pink (9/10/2013) 43 Then -- he overhears TALKING...

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPETER
dialogues.text: That’s what I heard... Andrew turns. Creeps around the corner. Sees a trio of fe Studio Band PLAYERS, all core, chatting. They don’t see h

dialogues.speaker: TRUMPETER
dialogues.text: Do you think he’ll make a complaint?

dialogues.speaker: SAXOPHONIST
dialogues.text: He wants a career. Long as Fletcher stays, Fudd could get placed back in. Why would he jeopardize that? Andrew leans in to hear more, but before he can get a rea

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I need to look at the music. Carl is inches from his face. Andrew turns to the chair - the folder is gone. His eyes go wide. No...

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I have it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW CARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, of course. I’m... Why isn’t it on you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW CARL
dialogues.text: It is, I-- I don’t see it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (realizing he can’t hide this) Fuck... I -- I think I fucked up...

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: No. You’re joking.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I swear to God, I had it on that chair--

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my God. Oh my God. How could you be so fucking stupid?!?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (shaking, doesn’t know what to do) A... A janitor... Maybe a janitor took--  Pink (9/10/2013) 44

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Find the fucking chart! ! (turns, grabs a passing player--) Neiman lost my folder.

dialogues.speaker: SAXOPHONIST
dialogues.text: Serious? Fletcher's going to flip. And just like that -- a VOICE booms down the hall--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Drums!! Where the hell is Tanner??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, terrified, Andrew behind him, addresses Fletcher--

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: We have an issue.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Now is not the time.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I gave Neiman the folder. Neiman lost it. Fletcher looks at Andrew. This is a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Neiman lost it.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: The folder is YOUR fucking responsibility, Tanner! You should have known not to give Neiman your folder. You give a retard a calculator and he’1ll try to turn his TV on with it. Now get your ass on-stage before I--

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I can’t...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Can’t what?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (doesn’t want to have to say this--) I -- I can’t go on-stage... I don’t know the charts by heart...  45 Pink (9/10/2013) 45

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Come again, darling?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: You know this... I have -- I need the music, my memory -- it’s, it needs visual cues--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Visual cues??

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: --it’s a medical conditio--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: A medical condition? What are you, Sanjay Gupta?? Play the fucking music!!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I can. Fletcher and Carl both look at him. Neither was expecting to chime in. Andrew seems almost as surprised...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You know “Whiplash” by heart?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. Every measure. Every note. Quickly realizing this is now his only option--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: You'd better pray your memory doesn’t fail you, Neiman. And I hope you've improved since last month’s rehearsal. I am not about to start losing now. Then, to the rest of the band--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLAYERS in their places. And there, on the set, overwhelmed, trying to make this one shot count -- is And

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCEMENT
dialogues.text: With their second selection, the Shaffer Conservatory Studio Band.  46 Pink (9/10/2013) 46 Fletcher faces the band. Zeroes in on Andrew. The wild-ca Andrew rubs the sweat from his palms. This is it, this is it... Adjusts the drums, tightens the snares. Carl sittin behind him, burning holes with his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Five-two-two-six-two-two... Six-two-two... Fletcher raises his arm. Hand suspended in air, finger wa to move... Andrew locks eyes on it. Heart pounding now... And -- the finger moves. The band begins WHIPLASH OVERBRO surging 7/4. Andrew seems caught off-guard at first. Stru to keep up. Then reaches the right speed -- and stays the Fletcher keeps his eye on him, waiting for him to fuck up But Andrew doesn’t. He gets the first hit. Awkward, but i time. Then the second hit -- also graceless, but on targe And here comes the key moment. Fletcher turns his attenti to the trumpets -- and away from Andrew. Barely believing his luck, Andrew plays another bar. Stil Fletcher doesn’t look at him. He’s focused on other playe The number builds some more. And--

dialogues.speaker: HEAD JUDGE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: First place. Shaffer Conservatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause. Fletcher summons his PLAYERS to the stage. The hands him the microphone. Fletcher takes it, hesitantly. band behind him -- including Andrew...

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I’m...supposed to say a few words but... it’s these kids who should be speaking... (turning to his band, earnestly) You earned this, gang. (beat, turns to the audience) You know... When I was a kid, I saw God. Or as some people know him, Charlie Parker. My dad snuck me out of school so we could make the drive into Chicago. It was a bar so he had to sneak me in, hidden under his coat. I didn’t know where in the hell I was. I was all of seven. But then, by the time I was on my third Shirley Temple, this nice- looking man went up on-stage and started playing. And I’ve never been the same since. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (turning again to his band) You guys mean the world to me, you know... (back to the audience) I think of them like they were my own kids. Treat them that way, too. Treat ‘em like my dad treated me. Meaning I terrorize them. (laughter, and to the band,) But it’s true, gang. You’re my family... Something about how Fletcher says this suggests he means FLETCHER (CONT’D) Thank you. Thank you so much. He wavers. Then steps aside and exits with his band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STAGE HAND appears, carrying a red folder. Going up t and Andrew--

dialogues.speaker: STAGE HAND
dialogues.text: This yours? I think a janitor threw it in the trash by accident. Carl looks. It’s his MUSIC FOLDER. He looks behind at And

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new day of rehearsal. Andrew enters the room, passes th

dialogues.speaker: PIANIST
dialogues.text: Don’t you go taking my folder... Andrew looks at him. Wary, he makes his way to the drums. to Carl. Reaches in to help Carl adjust the cymbals when-

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Do not touch the set. Andrew stops. Just then -- the DOOR OPENS, and Fletcher e

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: “Cherokee”. (looks at Carl) What are you doing? No answer. Carl, seated at the set, is visibly confused. FLETCHER (CONT’D) Core only today, I can’t waste time with alternates.  48 49 Pink (9/10/2013) 48 Carl stays still. What...? Andrew looks just as shocked. But Fletcher keeps on staring. He’s dead-serious. Finally slides off, stunned, as Andrew takes his place... And, ca tossing this off even though he knows how much it hurts--

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tanner, make sure to turn Neiman’s pages. Then he raises his hand. Andrew holds his sticks, still shocked. This is as clear a verdict of his playing at Overbrook as he’1ll ever get. He’s the new core drummer. Fletcher CLAPS the band off, and before we hear any music

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew watches a VIDEO on his iPhone... It’s 70's footage audio of a grey-haired DRUMMER, a face we’ve seen before. BUDDY RICH. Andrew smiles. Relaxed. Proud. A bubble pops up: “1 NEW VOICEMAIL, 1 NEW TEXT MESSAGE”. Andrew opens the text. The name on it: “NICOLE”. It reads “You free Thursday?" Andrew is about to answer. Hesitates. Plays the voicemail

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Neiman... You lost that folder on purpose. You knew I didn't know the chart by heart... Answer me... I've been core for two _ years. I've been drumming since I was three. I earned my spot you asshol-- Andrew hangs up. Looks back at the text message. Consider again... Then he just resumes watching the video. INT. NEW JERSEY - JIM’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - EVENING 49 Jim grabs a platter from the stove, Andrew by his side.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How’s it going in Studio Band?  50 Pink (9/10/2013) 49

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Good. I think he likes me more now.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: His opinion means a lot to you, doesn’t it? Jim looks at Andrew. Almost accusatory. A moment...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Grab the shakers please. INT. JIM’S HOUSE - DINING ROOM - NIGHT 50 Seven people seated at the table: Jim and Andrew, Andrew' uncle FRANK, aunt EMMA, and 18-year-old cousin DUSTIN. To

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Jimbo -- overcooked! (to Emma, laughing re: the meat) I can barely chew this thing. Jim laughs along. Andrew watches. There’s an undercurrent the joking. The power dynamic between the brothers is cle UNCLE FRANK (CONT’D) He just laughs. Jim keeps laughing.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMMA
dialogues.text: And how's your drumming going, Andy? Andrew, put on the spot, hesitates. But then, excited--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Well... Actually, it’s...it’s going really well. I’m now the core drum-- The door OPENS. In steps TRAVIS, another cousin, 21, foot player, real looker. All eyes swerve in an instant from Andrew to him.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, well, well -- Tom Brady!

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late.  Pink (9/10/2013) 50

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMMA
dialogues.text: Did you hear, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: They named Trav the season’s MVP.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That’s incredible, Tra--

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMMA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) And Dustin heading up Model UN, soon-to- be-Rhodes-Scholar or who knows what, Jim “Teacher of the Year” I mean, the talent at this table it’s stunning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Then-- AUNT EMMA (CONT’D) And Andrew. With his drumming.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, you said that was going ok, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (a little peeved, ) It's going spectacularly well, actually. I’m...I’m in Shaffer's top jazz orchestra, it’s the best in the country -- and I was just made a core member. (there’s no reaction) ...Which means I play in competitions. I’m one of the youngest they have.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: How do they know who wins in a music competition? Isn’t it subjective?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: -.-No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Does the studio help get you a job?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It’s...it’s not a studio, that’s just the name of the ensemble... And yes, it’s a big step forward in my career.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m just curious how you make your money as a drummer. After graduating.  Pink (9/10/2013) 51 Andrew glances at his dad. Wondering if maybe he’1l chime in defense... But no. His dad stays meek and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMMA
dialogues.text: I saw a TV commercial for credit reports where a young man was playing the drums. You could do that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes, or the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra. But the credit reports gig is a wonderful backup.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: (missing Andrew’s sarcasm) Well I’m glad you have it figured out. It’s a nasty business, I’m sure. (to Travis) Oh, you gotta tell them about your game last week. I’d say you lived up to your title.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: 43-yard touchdown to win it.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m talking about! On your way to the pros.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It’s Division III. Everyone at the table looks at Andrew -- including his da

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He plays for Carleton. It’s Division III. It’s not even Division II. (silence, shock around the table) The tilapia is delicious, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: (I‘1l get you back for that) You got a lot of friends, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: And why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don’t see the use.  Pink (9/10/2013) 52

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Well who will you play with otherwise? Who’1l give you your break? Lennon and McCartney were school buddies, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Charlie Parker didn’t know anyone ‘til Jo Jones threw a cymbal at his head.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: And that’s your idea of success, then?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Becoming the greatest musician of the twentieth century would be anyone’s idea of success.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Dying broke, drunk, and full of heroin at 34 would not be my idea of success. Andrew turns and looks at his dad. Can’t believe he joine

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (to his dad) I'd rather die broke and drunk at 34 and have people at a dinner table somewhere talk about it than die rich and sober at 90 and have no one remember me.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah, but friends remember you. That’s the whole point.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, none of us were Charlie Parker’s friends. That’s the whole point.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Well there’s such a thing as feeling loved and included.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I prefer to feel hated and cast out. It gives me purpose.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. You don’t mean that.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Travis and Dustin have plenty of friends, and I’d say they have plenty of purpose.  Pink (9/10/2013) 53

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You’re right, they’1l make great School Board presidents.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Oh -- so, that’s what this is all about -- you think you’re better than us?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You catch on quick. You must be in Model UN.

dialogues.speaker: TRAVIS
dialogues.text: Well I’ve got a reply for you, Andrew. You think Carleton football’s a joke? (Andrew only nods) Come play with us.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Four words you will never hear from the NFL.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMMA
dialogues.text: Who wants dessert?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And from Lincoln Center? A moment of silence. Andrew looks at his dad, and his dad just looks right back... A simmering anger in his eyes, Andrew turns to the others, and, slowly--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: In 1967 a scientist named Laszlo Polgar decides to prove talent isn’t about what you’re born with but about conditioning. Has three kids, Susan, Sophia and Judit, and gets them practicing chess for hours and hours before they can even talk. Fifteen years later Susan and Sophia are the two top female players in the world, and Judit’s on her way to entering the history books as the greatest female chess master of all time. Silence once again. Andrew glances at his dad, and delive back that same accusatory look he saw in the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: So not only do you want to die at 34, broke, drunk, and addicted to heroin, but you also wish you were a lab rat.  51 Pink (9/10/2013) 54 Andrew says nothing. Rises, plate in hand. Walks to the d

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Enjoy band camp.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Enjoy pretending you’re an ambassador. --and swings it shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Ok, I’m going to just lay it out. This is why I don’t think we should be together. We're back in the city, at a coffee shop. Andrew is seate across from Nicole, who just looks at him. Clearly she di not think this is how the conversation would begin.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve thought about this a lot. If we’re together this is what’s going to happen. I’m going to keep pursuing what I’m pursuing, and it’s going to take up more and more of my time. You’re going to see me less and less. When you do, I’‘1l be distracted, I’1l be upset, I'll be playing things in my mind. And you're going to just grow to resent me. At a certain point, you’1ll tell me to ease up on the drumming, to spend more time with you. And I won’t be able to. And I’11 start to resent you for even asking me that. I’1l feel like you’re dragging me down, you'll feel like you don’t matter -- and before long, we’ll hate each other. So I think we should just cut it off now, cleanly, for those reasons. A beat. Nicole is silent. Finally, Andrew adds--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because I want to be great.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And you’re not.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I want to be one of the greats.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And I would stop you from doing that.  52 Pink (9/10/2013) 55

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You know I would stop you from doing that. You know that for a fact.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And I would barely see you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: And when I did see you, you would treat me like shit, because I’m some girl who doesn’t know what she wants, and you have a path, and you're going to be great, and I’m going to be forgotten, and therefore you won't be able to give me the time of day because you have bigger things to pursue.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right. That’s exactly my point. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You’re right. We should not be dating. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I’m glad we had this talk.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Me too. With that, she turns and leaves. We linger on Andrew, the look on his face... Did I just fuck up...? No, I'm good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLAST of music. Horns squealing, cymbals swelling. It’s another Studio Band rehearsal. Andrew’s at the drums playing well. Fletcher cues a fermata, and the band finishes STUDIO BAND REHEARSAL AFTER-BREAKUP CHART.  Pink (9/10/2013) 56

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Alright, gang. Pick up the new chart by the door. Rehearsal tonight starts at 9. You have ‘til then to learn it. PLAYERS head out.
